results.title: The Power to change
results.creator_credit: Jamil Simon and Third Eye Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates alternatives to the traditional pattern of production, distribution and use of energy. Focuses on existing projects throughout the Untied Sates, including urban composting, solar energy on the arm, and wind-powered automobiles.

results.title: The Power that means progress, compressed air power
results.creator_credit: Colin Bell, James Carr and British Information Services
results.brief_description: How man uses compressed air power in various situations, from ligh to heavy use. Total information on developing the compressor equipment. Well filmed and edited and the information is well presented in a clear and understandable way.

results.title: The Power pinch
results.creator_credit: Victor Summa, Jane Kaplan and Integrated Video Services
results.brief_description: A documentary which examines sexual harassment of women in the workplace through interviews with women who have experienced sexual harassment and men who discuss their attitudes to the issue. Emphasis is placed on the economic, legal, and emotional ramifications. Explains the underlying causes of such behaviour and shows what all involved parties can do to prevent it. Hosted by Ken Howard.

results.title: The Power of Water
results.creator_credit: Chris McCullough, Peter Butt and Film Australia
results.brief_description: We all use electricity in our everyday lives. The Snowy Mountains Hydro Electric Scheme can produce essential peak load for all of New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory within minutes, and water to the Murray and Murrumbidgee irrigation system. “The power of water” looks at the workings and history of the Snowy Mountains Scheme from the early years of construction through to the most recent technological developments. A comprehensive guide on the Scheme introduces the processes which allow Australia’s greatest engineering project to produce a valuable and efficient form of energy - power from water.

results.title: The Power of the situation
results.creator_credit: Tuggelin Yourgrau, David Espar and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
This program looks at the ways in which people are influenced by leaders, groups and society - at social psychology. Psychological experiments by Lewin and Milgram, inspired by the extreme cruelty of the Nazi regime, suggest that, given the same circumstances, a powerful leader, peer group pressure, an extraordinary situation, everyone is capable of the same extremes of good or evil behaviour. Once the situation no longer exists we return to our “normal” selves. Archival film of these experiments is included.

results.title: The Power of positive influence
results.brief_description: This video training package (with accompanying trainer’s guide) aims to provide managers and team leaders with the skills to assert a positive influence on their team members. As a leader in any situation in any organisation, it is helpful to gain a better understanding of human nature and why people behave in certain ways. While motivation ultimately comes from within, managers can influence what their staff are motivated to do by providing a positive work environment, building confidence and self esteem, and personal empowerment.

results.title: The Power of one
results.creator_credit: John G. Avildsen, Arnon Milchan, Alcor Films, Regency Enterprises, Studio Canal+ and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Bryce Courtenay, this is the story of a young English boy named PK. Orphaned in a foreign land and terrorized for his political beliefs by his schoolmates, the pint-sized youngster turns to the only friend who can help him: a kindly yet world-wise prison inmate who teaches him how to box. As he grows into manhood, he takes on the system and social injustices which arise from Apartheid. Stars Stephen Dorff, Morgan Freeman and Sir John Gielgud and photographed by Australian Dean Semler. One person really can make a difference.

images.caption: The Power of one (John G. Avildsen) still

results.title: The Power of mentoring
results.brief_description: Mentoring is where an experienced individual invests time, energy and personal knowledge to assist another person. This management title discusses successful mentoring behaviours and follows two main mentoring relationships and their development. Also shown is a mentoring situation which isn’t working, demonstrating that mentoring requires an equal input from both partners. A 51 page training program accompanies this title.

results.title: The Power of Love
results.creator_credit: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.brief_description: The first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience was The Power of Love (1922), which used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour.

constellations_primary.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.description:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.
description_for_label:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.

results.title: The Power of listening
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the meaning and benefits of active listening, problems associated with being an effective listener, deterrents to good listening skills and specific techniques to improve listening abilities.
